org.rootsdev.polygenea

Class Node

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.rootsdev.polygenea.Node
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.Comparable<Node>
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    Citation, Claim, InferenceRule, Note, Source

    public abstract class Node
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Comparable<Node>
    Node is a superclass of all Polygenea node objects. It handles JSON serialisation (via reflection), UUID creation (via UUID5.fromUTF8 for nodes without identity, UUID.randomUUID for nodes with Identity), and portions of JSON parsing (aided by special constructors in each subclass).

    Writers of subclasses should be aware of the following assumptions of this class:

    • All serialisable attributes of a node are declared as public final fields.
    • Every node has a JSON-reading constructor that accepts a JSON object and a NodeLookup object. See the Note class for a simple stand-alone example of what these might look like.
    • All fields should have a well-defined canonical representation. Thus, the interfaces SortedMap and SortedSet are preferred over Map and Set; SortedSet is also preferred over most other Collections, with the exception that List is permissible if (and only if) the order of elements of the list has semantic significance.
    • Fields containing objects (as opposed to primitives) should be immutable. String is immutable by design, but most other classes are not. The various Collections.unmodifiable___ methods are useful here.
    Subclass writers are also encouraged to override the Node.validate(StringBuilder log) method, calling super.validate(log) somewhere inside; and to make the last line of each concrete class's constructor be this.selfCheck(). While not essential, these practices can help detect a variety of potential problems at node creation time rather than later when the nodes are in use or are being serialised.
    Author:
    Luther Tychonievich. Released into the public domain. I would consider it a courtesy if you cite my contributions to any code derived from this code or project that uses this code.
    See Also:

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Class and Description
      static class  Node.JSONificationException
      Generated by the various string parsing methods if the input is not a DAG string or if it is not a stand-alone string and the parsing DAG doesn't have the needed nodes.
      static interface  Node.XRefer
      There are various ways a Node might be represented in JSON: as its UUID, its index, or as an object; and if as an object it might or might not contain a !uuid field and might represent any nested Nodes in various ways as well.

    • Method Detail

      • hasIdentity

        public boolean hasIdentity()

      • getHeight

        public int getHeight()
        Nodes form a directed acyclic graph. As such, each can be given a height. A leaf node (one where out().size() == 0) has height 0. Every other node's height is 1 + the maximum height of any of its out() nodes.

        Height is primarily useful for serialising nodes such that dependencies precede nodes that depend upon them.

        Height is computed on demand the first time this method is invoked on a node, but is thereafter cached for future reference.

        Returns:
        The height of this node (≥ 0)

      • getUUID

        public final java.util.UUID getUUID()
        If the node has a uuid, it is returned. Otherwise one is generated using either type-5 (if !hasIdentity) or type-4 (if hasIdentity).
        Returns:
        This node's UUID.

      • validate

        public boolean validate(java.lang.StringBuilder log)
        Performs any validation that the node might need. The Node class just checks the UUID. Subclasses should override this method to perform any additional validation they might need, such as verifying that fields are not null.
        Parameters:
        log - A place where descriptions of problems will be written. If the node is valid, log is not used.
        Returns:
        true if the node is valid, false otherwise.

      • hashableJSON

        public java.lang.String hashableJSON()
        A full JSONification except there is no "!uuid" field; used to compute digest-based hashes.
        Returns:
        A valid JSON object string representing this node

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        A full JSONification, suitable for saving the node to disk or sharing the node with other computers.
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object
        Returns:
        A valid JSON object string representing this node

      • compressedJSON

        public static java.lang.String compressedJSON(Node... nodes)
        Returns a JSON list string with compressed JSON object strings inside. Compression removed "!uuid" fields from non-identity nodes and represents cross-references with indices if the node being references is in the list returned. Nodes are returned in an order that guarantees that, if a node and its dependencies are both in the output, the node will appear after the nodes on which it depends.
        Parameters:
        nodes - The nodes to represent in a JSON list.
        Returns:
        A JSON list of JSON objects.

      • jsonify

        public static void jsonify(java.lang.StringBuilder sb,
                           java.lang.Object o,
                           Node.XRefer detail)
        A convenience method for creating canonical JSON of primitives, Sets, Lists, Maps, UUIDs, and Nodes
        Parameters:
        sb - The StringBuilder into which to place the JSON.
        o - The object to JSONify. Nested Nodes are represented as UUID strings.
        detail - If o is a Node, this describes how it will be represented.

      • fromJSON

        public static Node fromJSON(java.util.SortedMap<java.lang.String,java.lang.Object> sm,
                            NodeLookup nodes)
        Turns a JSON-returned object containing a Node and turns it back into a Node object. It does this via the special "!class" and "!uuid" fields of the input.
        Parameters:
        sm - The parsed JSON containing a single node,
        nodes - A place to look up nodes referenced by index or UUID.
        Returns:
        A Node subclass representation of the provided map.
        Throws:
        JSONParser.MalformedJSONException - if the "!class" field doesn't match the data.
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the "!uuid" field is in error or the data is otherwise corrupted or incomplete.

      • fromJSON

        public static Node fromJSON(java.lang.String json,
                            NodeLookup nodes)
        Turns a JSON-encoded String containing a single Node into a Node object. It does this via the special "!class" and "!uuid" fields of the input.
        Parameters:
        json - The json string to parse
        nodes - A place to look up nodes referenced by index or UUID.
        Returns:
        A Node subclass representation of the provided map.
        Throws:
        JSONParser.MalformedJSONException - if the input is not valid JSON, is not a JSON object, or the "!class" field doesn't match the data.
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the "!uuid" field is in error or the data is otherwise corrupted or incomplete.

      • dependsOn

        public java.util.Collection<Node> dependsOn()
        Returns:
        a list of all nodes this Node references, transitively down to nodes with no references. May repeat some Nodes.

      • out

        public java.util.Collection<Node> out()
        Returns:
        a list of all nodes this Node references directly. May repeat some Nodes.

      • compareTo

        public int compareTo(Node that)
        Comparison is performed based on UUID only. This is important because it is part of how serialisation (and thus UUID computation) works.
        Specified by:
        compareTo in interface java.lang.Comparable<Node>

      • equals

        public boolean equals(java.lang.Object that)
        Equality is performed based class and UUID only, to match compareTo. Assuming that UUIDs are actually unique, that is fine.
        Overrides:
        equals in class java.lang.Object

      • validate

        public final boolean validate(java.io.Writer log)
        Performs any validation that the node might need. The Node class just checks the UUID.

        Do not override this method; override validate(StringBuilder) instead.

        Parameters:
        log - A place where descriptions of problems will be written. If the node is valid, log is not used.
        Returns:
        true if the node is valid, false otherwise.
